text: yeah so in high school I actually spent a lot of time playing around with tools like my Dreamweaver Photoshop and I
think I would have gotten to art school but just learning these tools was so incredibly hard I decided to major in
computer science and so I got to Stanford and when I started my PhD at
the time it seemed like everyone here was working on problems in big data and machine learning and I certainly got
swept up in that wave and I finally settled on a dissertation topic around
how to leverage data to build better design tools or scaffold the design
process and at the time there are all of these amazing repositories of design
also popping up on the web like for fonts and interior design and 3d models
and videos but where where I started was let's treat the the web itself as a
design repository and so my dissertation work focused on mining design on the web
at scale and allowing designers web designers to search through these
examples to find inspiration understand design patterns understand the space of
possible solutions and so what this allowed us to do was build systems where
you know people could search over the web of design so if you were a coffee
shop and you wanted to rebrand your website you could say show me coffee websites with maybe large photographic
backgrounds to see how people were integrating you know photos into their
web sites similarly you might be you know creating a mobile version of your
page and you're wondering where should that signup form go should it go at the top of the page or the bottom of the
page and so this is the types of systems that I was building as part of my
dissertation work I was very fortunate enough to be working with an amazing team at the time and we won a few best
paper Awards on this work we also decided at that time because people were asking can can we use these
tools to productize it and we were able to raise some money from andreessen
horowitz and MEA to actually go and see if we could build this into a product
and a business but what we found was in
the market was that examples by themselves that's not enough they
actually had just very marginal value and so while we had a few thousand
designers using these tools that we'd built we found that the usage of the tools was very epochal and by that I
mean people would use these tools during the first few days of their three-week
long design project so you know they would be using the tools to do research
and competitive analysis but then you know they would actually go off and create their designs and iterate on them
and then there were they were never coming back to the tool and so it really felt like we were working on the wrong
problem herb Simon says everyone designs who devices courses of action is aimed
at changing execs existing situations into preferred ones and I think the
important word here is preferred because my startup we were helping designers
understand the space of possible solutions but it was only when we started to help them understand what was
preferable that we finally saw some traction so you know when we built these
analytics platforms that showed how design features actually correlate with
specific you know key performance indicators like time on site our bounce
rate that was when people started to kind of continuously use data in the
design process and this kind of is borne out in other domains as well people have
similar questions about how to tie design features to performance our preferred outcomes and so for example
you know in mobile design people might want to know how many steps should a checkout flow take so that they can
prevent user fatigue or if you're creating an outfit you might want to say
how can you look smart without looking stuffy and if you're designing a recommendation engine and
using you know social network as data you might say how can you uncover taste
and taste makers in the social network so this is kind of what my research is
about these days and this is kind of what the rest of the talk is going to be about it's how to use data to tie design
decisions to desired outcomes so let's start by looking at how we can do this
for the domain of mobile app design what's the preferred outcome for a
mobile app well app designers care about a lot of things probably the thing they
care the most is that people are able to perform the tasks on apps that they
actually you know want them to be able to perform or do so things like task
completion rate lower completion time fewer usability issues building building
UIs that are accessible these are all preferred outcomes and you know when we
say data-driven design in the space what we usually mean is a be testing and a/b
testing is very useful for understanding causal relationships between design choices and key performance indicators
but at the same time it is hard to get statistical significance so this is a
recent white paper that was released by a company called qubit where they actually did a meta analyses over 6,700
large e-commerce experiments and this was mostly in the retail and travel
sectors and they found that 90% of the experiments actually have less than 1.2
percent effect on revenue now I'm not walking on a bee design because even a
point four percent lift for a big company that's 15 million dollars so you know that's real money but this is kind
of my point where a bee testing makes sense for large companies so if you're a Google or a Facebook and you have enough
users to run these tests you have enough money and engineering resources to
actually build out alternatives and deploy them this is a great way to continuously optimize your design but
what about everyone else right what we'd like is to have data at scale to help us
make this as decisions without having to be Google or Facebook and for most
designers they don't have access to this kind of data the data at their own companies will be small and you know
while they would like to be using data from maybe other companies to make more
informed decisions all of this data is locked away and siloed away within each
company so the the motivation here in this in this research direction is can
we open source usability and usage analytics so that everyone can learn
from them so I'm going to present you kind of one solution point in this space
and so we built a system called zipped which stands for 0 integration performance testing and at a high level
what it looks like is a designer can define different tests or tasks they
want done over any Android app in the Play Store so you can pick it Android up
and you can say do this task on this Android app and then what zipped
actually does is it will put this test on a crowdsource platform like Mechanical Turk and it will ask users to
perform this task on this app it will collect all of these multiple traces
from all these users and then it will aggregate that data and provide people
with visualizations that will help kind of up level design insights
so there's kind of two parts to this project right you are two challenges rather one challenge is you have to
actually be able to capture this data and then the second part is like you have to be able to efficiently aggregate
this data so let's talk about how we how we could do the capture the capture was
actually done by a system we built called Erica which allowed us to mine interaction traces on Android apps as
they were being used and the the point that I really want you guys to remember is that this rate we wanted it to
require no modifications to an app source code or binary so that we could
actually collect this data from apps that you personally didn't build and so
what are you do at a fuel for what Erika looks like and what Erika provides is a
web application for crowd workers to interact with mobile apps streamed from
a device farm so the apps are actually running on a device farm and a user is using the app through a web application
that we built and while users are interacting with an app what Erika is
doing is it's continuously capturing three types of data in the background first it's capturing user interaction
data so it actually knows where you tapped on the screen all right you know what your multi-touch gesture was it's
also collecting the screenshot so that's the set of pixels on the screen it's also getting anything called a UI
hierarchy which you can think of as like the drum tree of an Android app and what
that reflects is kind of the structure of the UI and what are all the elements
and what we do is we actually stitch all of this data together into these user
interaction traces so we know exactly how a user went from one screen to the
next like where did they click to go to the next screen we also collect the
screenshots at a high enough resolution so that we can actually capture animation effects on playback so what
you're seeing right here is our data being played back as video and so you can see like we're capturing
those animation effects as well one of the things as we collected this data
that we wanted to be cognizant about was minimizing the capture of people's
personally identifying information so crowd workers are using these apps we don't want them to give away things like
their credit card information their emails and things like that so we provided an interface where we basically
gave people accounts to use and there are some little technical challenges
that we had to solve here like figuring out how to do add verification steps so
so we figured that stuff out so let's go back so that's how capture works and
that's the type of data we collected let's go back and now talk about how we actually aggregate data over several
interaction traces and the key here actually is that we're going to leverage
all of that structure we captured in it in order to do this aggregation pretty efficiently so for example let's say a
designer put up this task unzipped where they wanted a crowd worker to log that
they ate a chocolate chip cookie on the app calorie counter so let's pretend
that we went ahead and posted this unzipped we collected user traces and
now we want to actually look at the results so what I'm going to show you next is kind of the dashboard we provide
designers so first of all we provide them some aggregate metrics such as the
average time on tasks the number of interactions that the average number of
interactions that were taken and completion rate so for this task it
seems like everyone was able to complete it similarly we aggregate feedback
answers to feedback questions as well so this gives us more insight about the users and who they are
you know have they used an Android before have they used the app before but this is customizable so as a designer
you can provide these feedback questions then we provide this flow visualization
interface and let's let's look at this a bit more closely so the goal here is to
tell people kind of in an aggregate sense or tell designers in an aggregate
sense how people actually completed that task and so what you see in the dark gray is what we're calling the designers
golden trace so this is how the designer intended someone to do the task on the app everything else is a deviation from
that so you can tell that even though that you know the completion rate for this task was a hundred percent not
everyone is doing this task as efficiently as possible and the question might be why you can also kind of like
get a feel for the screens that people are going through on the side and you might notice that there's a screen that
says hey there was a problem and so this modal has popped up right that says
there's a problem so maybe people are experiencing some some usability issue
here where they can't get to the next step and after you do a deep dive you
can actually see that hey it's actually confusing on this screen because people
actually had to enter in a unit for a chocolate chip cookie to go to the next
screen on this app and it wasn't clear from the interface itself that you had to do that so this is kind of the the
way zipped works and how it can be used to get usability insights as well as
design performance insights over apps you didn't create now let's kind of show
you a few case studies this is one of my favorite ones that we did so we were
here we were trying to compare YouTube music to Spotify music and we were the
tasks we wanted people to do was a simple one we just wanted people to create or we wanted people to add two
songs to a new playlist that they created and what we found
with more than 35 users doing this task was that there is a difference between those completion rates on this task
YouTube music only 89% well I should say 89% completed the task whereas more
users completed it on Spotify yes so
we're measuring great question there's a few ways to measuring completion one is self report and then
another one was answer based so you might have people do a task and produce
an answer like what was the address of blah blah blah and as long as they produce the right answer then they were
able to complete the task but in other situations they have to self report that they completed it and but yeah in this
case it was based on self-report and here we're asking so yeah we were
wondering why is there a difference between these completion rates and we did a deeper dive into the feedback
questions that were asked and it turns out that on YouTube there's not a way to
create an empty playlist and then add songs to it the way you actually create
new playlist is you have to go to a song and you have to then say add two new
playlist and that's how you create it yeah listen instead of critically
listening to your songs to you I was wondering did you try phrasing question the other way and see if things never
changed how it was phrased when we tried it but yeah I think it would have been worse if we had phrased it the other way
because they would have implied that you had to go first create a new playlist yeah yes so we just happened to phrase
that this way but it could have been yeah the results could have been worse I guess this is actually a known problem
in YouTube in the sense I talked to their one of their head designers and I just checked like a few days ago and
they still haven't fixed it so okay so
the the last example I want to actually show you as a comparison we did between
Macy's and best and we had a simple task which was find
the address of the store closest to a particular zip code so you're just kind of looking for the near the nearest
let's say retail store and what I'm showing you here is the golden trace
that let's say the designer would have intended so you know you have to click on the hamburger icon and there's a
flyout menu navigation and it takes six interactions to get to the right answer
so here's a case where completion rate is based on a right answer because we're phrasing the task as a question
similarly on Best Buy if you were performing the same task there's actually two ways you can do it
there's a there way there's a way which uses tap navigation which is just you
know on there on the the the first screen or that you can go through a
search route so a priori we were thinking that hey this is a shorter
interaction and there's actually two ways to complete the task so you know Best Buy should perform better and what
we actually found in practice was that Macy's was easier for people and it's
interesting because I think five years ago everyone was telling me don't use
hamburger menu icons they're hiding all of the you know capabilities you should
just make it more clear to the user what you can do on an app when you're on the home screen but now people are just so
used to this design pattern that if you don't use one you might end up confusing users so it's kind of interesting how
you know these design trends might change over time and I the reason I said
people actually found this use easier was they actually self-reported it being easier I think a lot of people on the
Best Buy got confused by the search experience because you had to be in the
right search mode to actually search for stores and not products and so we saw users who are trying to search for store
locations in the product search search bar so let's take a step back and talk
about what are the implications of the system well we're you know giving a way for people to test earlier in the design
process right because you don't have to go out and build out all of these different design alternatives you can
actually leverage existing apps and you can run tests on them and when you are

that knowledge to design your own flows it also gives you a way to do
comparative design testing at scale so if you wanted to you know compare a Best
Buy up to a Macy's app right now the only kind of service out there that you
can use is user testing comm where they will actually video you know a user take
a screen video of a user using an app to do different tasks and it's around 50 dollars a user and the reason it's
around 50 dollars a user is because someone has to manually go through and then annotate those videos and figure
out like what's happening in our case because we're collecting kind of this
structured data about interaction it's easier for us to automatically aggregate
this data and to surface you know insights about it and then
finally the the thing that is interesting about zipped I think is the
way you can combine different types of quantitative and qualitative findings and use that to inform each other you
know you can first find that there's a problem and then you can say you know why is that problem happening how can we
fix it so I think this is a this is a testing form where you can both figure
out the how and or what and the why now
I I think there's one important thing that is not yet exposed in this testing
interface and that is higher level design semantics so all the design descriptions we've collected are very
low level right I showed you a flow visualization and the reason we're able to do those is
because we've understood that two screens are basically the same but what
we want to really understand is like across apps when are you know two screens are two floats basically the
same what are people doing search interactions what are people doing checkout interactions when are people
you know clicking on an article like we need to understand those higher-level
semantics so kind of the next step in this work is actually figuring out what
these design semantics are and also being able to automatically identify them in the traces so in order to
actually do this work we had to collect data set big enough to where we could

capture technology as Erika and so actually I would love if you guys if you

people use this data set it provides interaction traces for around 10,000
Android apps which means more than 72 thousand unique you eyes which is there
approximately 3 million UI elements and so we use this data set to first
identify you know what should be a lexicon of UX concepts and we coded 73
thousand potential icons and 130 thousand text buttons that were in this
data set and by potential icons I mean images that are small and squarish that
appear in the in the UI hierarchy and we use this to basically identify around a
hundred eighty concepts UX concepts and if you're curious about the lexicon you
can also check it out at the URL on the on that slide there are some interesting
patterns we found where certain concepts or only usually expressed as text so you can have things
like log in and subscribe you won't ever find icons for these concepts similarly
you can have icons that are roughly synonyms such as you know the pencil
type icon and the plus sign usually signify an action like create and then
finally you can even have icon polysomes which are interesting because these are icons that can have slightly different
meaning depending on the context for example the star I mean context could be
used for rating and in another context can be used for favoriting or
bookmarking so we leverage this icon too
or we leverage this UX lexicon to then create an automatic approach for
identifying design semantics and Android apps and so we built this code and
vision based approach where we identify twenty five you I component categories
197 text button concepts and around 99
icon classes so given a screen shot and a UI hierarchy we can produce the
semantic version of that UI hierarchy basically the tricky bit in this
pipeline was actually the icons themselves because for a lot of the other a lot of the other types of
components you can use basic code based heuristics and they work pretty well for
Android apps but icons are again very hard to differentiate just from images
and so we actually trained a convolutional neural net that detects
between these 99 classes of icons and we also use anomaly detection at the end of
the pipeline so we can differentiate between icon classes as well as just other content based things where it's
just a small image so I want to show you some of the the classification results
it's cool because the average icons you produce for the different classes really
show that they're you know people are very consistent with the way they design icons and that you think this is why the
you know machine learning algorithm is able to learn something but you can see
that there's also some variation in each class where you know people do take
their own stylistic you know there's some room for style basically so once we
had kind of these element based semantics what we wanted to see is can
we bootstrap higher-level semantics based on these element level ones and so
for example can we understand screen semantics was the question and what we did was we trained a deep autoencoder to
basically capture semantics to see if we can capture semantic properties over
screens and what we were able to do is show that hey if you train an
autoencoder with those semantic versions of the screenshots that we produced we
can actually learn a space where if you do nearest neighbors nearest neighbors queries in the space you get back
semantically similar screens so if you query you as a login screen you will get
back other types of login screens from other apps so these none of these

the great thing was we were collecting interaction data so if someone clicks on

and so we built this facebook Messenger bot initially that connects users to
one-on-one sessions with stylists and we released this bot for three weeks our
stylists were Fashion Institute of Technology students so they weren't
experts but they were they were still more knowledgeable about fashion than let's say the average consumer we
advertised on Facebook and Instagram and we said hey are you looking for free fashion advice thing this bot and
through that mechanism we collected 88 organic styling conversations with 73
unique users now there's actually a lot
of convergence in terms of the types of problems people wanted solved definitely
the main problem everyone had was being able to describe context for which they
were trying to dress so they were trying to go to a wedding and they wanted to you know something to wear to that they
were going to a conference next week what should they wear for that what should they wear for an interview so these questions around context really
matter to people similarly people also have a hard time with matching things so
if they're creating outfits they don't know what goes with gray slacks and then finally people actually came on and use
the bot to just do product search so they would say I'm looking for a pair of boots
now ecommerce sites already support this type of interaction but it's interesting
that people would still come to the bot for this because one could hypothesize
that people are just overwhelmed with the set of choices that they're given through search engines and they're never
provided kind of justification about whether you know why one set of pair of
boots is better than the other pair of boots we also studied the interaction
patterns that the stylists were using in order to address these questions and so
the most interesting pattern to us was the fact that they were using these multimodal responses and by multimodal I
mean they use images texts and so you people just never throw up an image and say hey this is my
recommendation right people always give an image and then explain why it kind of
fit the requirements the user was looking for similarly they use the same
pattern when they're trying to help users kind of refine their own problem because if someone comes to the bottom
says I need shoes like there are a lot of types of shoes out there right so you
need to then ask questions and show examples to help users refine their
problem enough so you can actually help them and so they use the same multimodal
pattern in both contexts and the word code-switching is on that slide because
it's a very important one in this context apparently when people talk
about fashion they use different languages like experts use different language from you know the average
consumer but the thing you have to realize is that the expert still needs to communicate in a way that the average
consumer can understand so even when they have all of this expertise and
knowledge they have to you know kind of translate between the two languages and
we saw this happen all the time so this kind of like set up the set of design

these requirements first let's talk about how this deals with compatibility
so there's a part of this architecture where we've trained a visual
compatibility model from 70,000 fashion outfits we actually got these outfits
from a social media site called poly boar which unfortunately no longer is up
they took it down this summer but before they took it down we were able to mine
this data and we will it is available we will make it available so you can also use it but
basically at a high level how we did this was we wanted to satisfy that I
mean there there have been people who have been modeling compatibility in fashion but the insight we had was that
if you only trained one embedding in this space you are necessarily requiring things
that match a thing to be similar to each other which is not always true so for
example two shoes that match the same top are not necessarily similar to each
other things get matched for different reasons and so the insight here for us was let's train multiple embedding so
that you can allow for things to match in different ways the other point we the
other requirement we cared about was it being multimodal so what we did was we
took the visual embedding from the compatibility model and we trained a
neural regressor basically to map the visual embedding to 1300 text concepts
in fashion and we created that vocabulary of text concepts as well so
that that wasn't something that was just out there and standard and then finally
we also cared a lot about code switching right because I said there's some
vocabulary that's used by experts and some that's just so low-level are sorry
there's some language that average consumers use and this this is really
interesting because it it's been studied by fashion theorists for a while so
rolling Bart you know wrote in his the language of fashion like what makes a
sweater smart is it the fact that it's you know a sweater because it's silk
because it's white because it's square neck like what are the attributes the low-level features of fashion that makes
a sweater smart and so this is kind of the problem or the this is the kind of
thing we want to learn or capture and our first attempt at this was training poly lingual topic models I
won't get into this in great detail but what we were able to do is basically
Express every outfit as a distribution over topics and each topic could be
expressed as a set of style words or instead of low-level element words and
it powered interactions where people could give a bunch of text describing
what they wanted and they could get item recommendations for them so this is something where someone describes you

inference here doesn't really work when you have small documents and so in when

scale you know this was not appropriate for the types of interactions we wanted

learning the distribution over all the concepts the 13-hundred concept and in the second step we're going to actually

neuron per concept and this actually really helps with the the terms that
